Subject: Alternative speciation strategies...

Hi,

	I've been thinking about speciation a bit more, and in particular in 
the context of my current SLEAT situation...

	The problem I have, is that (this is with fairly standard 
speciation, after Ken's original) I get very rapid progress at first, 
when increasing the fitness from ~-56% to ~90% but then then it hits 
a region of really sharp diminishing returns where improvements to 
the population champion get further and further apart.

	My take on this is that it is getting harder and hard to find any 
additional structure that can be added which doesn't disrupt 
something in the existing genome (and which isn't completely inert).

	This is also affected by my trimming strategy.  Trimming is 
performed periodically.  It has the effect of evaluating every 
feature of the genome, and if removing it does not reduce fitness, 
discarding it.

	Trimming is necessary to keep genomes down to reasonable sizes.  It 
is obviously a bit of a hack.  If CPU were no object, then one could 
avoid anything like this altogether, and just allow the natural 
balance of the insert and delete mutations (*) to arrive at an 
equilibrium genome size (**).  Of course, I could just increase the 
deletion probability until the natural size was not too large.  But 
the risk there is, since some proportion of the genome will be 
required to make the individual fit, too high a deletion rate will 
just swamp the system with individuals who all have "something 
missing" and have to be eliminated.

	[[(*) yes, I have deletion mutations in this

	  (**) the insertion rate is not dependent on the number of elements
	        in the genome, but deletion is considered once per element,
                   therefore, left to itself, the genome would increase until
	        insert_chance = delete_chance * num_elements...

	        if there was selection against larger genomes this would
	        also push on this balance]]

	A consequence of trimming is that any new structure that is going to 
develop and improve the champion, has to become adaptive _before_ a 
trimming cycle comes around and hacks it out.  Not that I've seen any 
problem with that in earlier stages...

	So, you can see that the stagnation of the search might be down to 
the required developments in later stages requiring more time than is 
available between trims.  BUT, conversely, if trimming were left too 
infrequent (or off) then the individual genomes would grow to such a 
size than the individual cycles would slow to a crawl, whether they 
were going to find anything or not...

--

	So...

	I've been thinking about speciation, not quite from the 
point-of-view of Ken's "preserving innovation" idea.  But from the 
related idea of "separating (less fit) newcomers from the mainstream 
so that they can be evolved to their full potential" - and then 
seeing if what they had learned can be usefully merged into the mainstream.

	Before I start I have:

	  "Theorum #1" -- a single species that is making progress (becoming 
fitter) at some reasonable rate, needs no extra-species interaction 
(splitting, merging or cross-breeding).

	((This says nothing about whether any other species might exist, 
just that we need not interact with them at this time...))

	And "Theorum #2" -- that the only purpose of a second (or more) 
species, is if it (i) replaces, or (ii) contributes genetic 
information to the mainstream.

	((Obviously it can try to do that, fail and be made extinct, but its 
objective must be to do one of those two.))

	OK, so types of speciation:

--

Type Zero Speciation

	The simplest thing we could ever do, is to mimic the effect of 
geographical separation in natural species.  e.g. if there is a 
natural species that is well adapted to its environment, and 
something happens to divide it in two (like a land-bridge eroding), 
then we are left with two identical populations, being selected under 
the same constraints, but no-longer constrained to remain the 
same.  In nature what you then get is that the random component to 
evolution (known as "genetic drift") causes them to drift apart; and 
eventually become mutually infertile (***) and thus, by definition, 
not the same species (****).

	[[ (***) or just less-fertile, that's enough to select
	          for not wanting to interbreed.

	   (****) 	there might also be an argument here about immortality...
	           	because if there are immortal individuals in a species,
	           	they effectively also act as a brake on genetic drift
	           	(because anyone who is not fertile with the immortals,
	            is at a disadvantage, either just because there is a part
		of the population they can't breed with, or because the
		immortals are by definition the fittest individuals)]]

	I call this type zero speciation, because it is the very minimum 
that speciation can ever be, e.g. two populations that have been 
separated but are not in any other way driven to differ.

	To do this on a computer, you can do various things, such as: (i) 
split the individuals in the existing species equally into two new 
species, (ii) clone the whole existing species but make sure than one 
copy gets different random numbers.

--

Bottleneck Speciation

	If 99.9% of a species is wiped out, then the randomly selected group 
of survivors can go on to repopulate the whole thing.  In a natural 
scenario, this might reflect the survivors of some large-scale 
catastrophe.  Less dramatically, however, the same thing can happen 
if just a few members of a new species get transported to a new 
habitat -- the small number of individuals that arrive will father a 
whole new population.

	I don't think this is a very good model for computer-based 
studies.  Natural species are huge and complex and contain a wide 
variety of alternative gene forms (alleles, in genetics speak) all of 
which are reasonably fit.  Thus, when a bottle-neck happens to a 
natural species, what happens is that the subset of those varied 
alleles that happen to be present in the small group of founders get 
boosted to population-spanning ubiquity.  So the new population is 
_immediately_ different from the old one.  Our populations, OTOH. , 
tend to be small (< 1,000,000 individuals :) ) and homogeneous.  So 
bottlenecking one is actually far less of a change than for a natural 
system (I almost listed this with the previous category...)

--

Side-step Speciation

	This is where it starts to get interesting.  The idea of a side-step 
is that we are going to take the existing species, change it by some 
moderate amount (*****) and then set it evolving again from its new 
start point.

	[[ (*****) moderate in the sense of not trivially small, but not so 
far that it is unrelated ]]

	You can regard this as some sense of "giving the system a kick" to 
try and shake it out of the cosy local optimum it is stuck in.  The 
obvious way to implement this is to copy N individuals out of the old 
species, subject them to M cycles of unselected mutation, and then 
set them going as the new species.

	If N is too large, then the chance will be that some individual will 
be effectively unchanged and the new species will carry on just like 
the original one did.  OTOH, N > 1 might have the advantage of a far 
lesser chance of seeding the new species with a completely lame individual...

	The equivalent of this in nature can probably only occur when (i) a 
small group get separated from the species and (ii) they pick up a 
lot of mutations.  That probably only happens in (a) nuclear war or 
(b) if they have wandered into a new environment where the selection 
pressures are different, so they accumulate extra mutations not 
because they are mutating faster, but because selection can no longer 
discriminate against them (obviously this latter is slower than we 
see in typical computer experiments)...

	The resulting species from this may hold an advantage in two ways 
that I will describe in the next section...

--

Try-again Speciation

	Another interesting one.  To do this what you do is take some 
individuals from a fit species and delete the same (random) genome 
feature from each of them (another use for innovation 
numbers...).  These individuals then form a new species, and may be 
quite unfit, but they only have to re-evolve the subsystem that you 
deleted, not start completely from scratch.  In doing that they will 
either (i) re-evolve an exact equivalent of what was deleted (will 
especially happen if the deletion was too small), (ii) evolve 
completely from scratch, losing their pre-existing approach 
(especially if the deletion is too small), or (iii) re-evolve a new 
approach to the section that was deleted.

	It is that final case which is the interesting one, because when 
they evolved the original feature, certain random decisions were made 
and subsequently "locked in" to the strategy of the species.  By 
forcing that fragment to re-evolve, we give the system a chance to 
find either (i) a fitter approach, or (ii) an approach with different 
strengths and weaknesses.  In the former case, real progress has been 
made and the new species can replace the old one.  In the latter 
case, the new species is less fit than the old one, but may handle 
some aspects of the situation better, and we may get some advances 
from merging the two species.

--

OK, so that's some notes on alternative speciation.

	I'm currently working up to implementing side-step and try-again 
approaches in SLEAT.  In a day or so I will mail again about ideas 
for merging branched species back into the mainstream and retaining 
the advantages of both...

	[[I am also interested in using "type zero" as the form of parallel 
processing that I think I mentioned late last year, where you branch 
the population into N copies with different random number seeds (e.g. 
on remote machines) and after M generations select the fittest 
version and discard the others.]]

	Ian
In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
